stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on UV mapping and designing a volcano area for the game's overworld. The stream was dominated by significant technical difficulties with Blender's performance, which were eventually solved by installing a community-made N64-specific renderer. He also officially revealed Luigi's inclusion in the game and discussed future plans for side levels and an upcoming period of dedicated streaming.

development_findings.summary: A new quality-of-life feature has been added: a dialog box that lets the player choose to exit the level or stay after collecting a star.
development_findings.quote: I was working on the exit course dialog. After you get a star, you can now just exit the course. I don't know if you remember in demo, you would just stay. That's a bit awkward, I think.

development_findings.summary: The overworld is being designed to be a single, large, dynamically-loading map to ensure visual consistency between areas, such as a large tree being visible from multiple viewpoints.
development_findings.quote: After your pass is done, I'm going to make this all into one big level that loads dynamically as you walk through it.

development_findings.summary: Course 7 is complete and has been sent out for beta testing.
Luigi has been imported into the game, but his function (co-op, unlockable character, etc.) is still undecided.
Kaze estimates a potential release by the end of the year, but jokingly suggests this timeline is dependent on external factors like his employment status.
development_findings.quote: The game has a good chance of being done by the end of the year. Maybe like if I lose my job.

development_findings.summary: The game runs fully on real N64 hardware and is being targeted for compatibility with the Analogue 3D.
Kaze experienced severe performance issues with Blender 4.1, which crippled his workflow until he installed the F64 renderer add-on at the suggestion of a community member (Lila).
development_findings.quote: This is a whole stream of just fucking waiting for Blender to do its thing. This is a nightmare.

development_findings.summary: The current ROM size is approximately 59.95 MB, leaving little room under the 64 MB limit.
A side level concept was discussed involving infiltrating an oil tanker to unlock a level called 'Oily Body Bay', indicating that some level unlock requirements are still being formalized.
development_findings.quote: Wait, did we ever... We never wrote this formally down, did we? There's a whole mission you have to do to unlock this?

development_findings.summary: Kaze is trying to eliminate all compile warnings from the project, indicating a focus on code quality and stability.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes many philosophical concepts, like Kant's categorical imperative, are either painfully obvious or fundamentally flawed and delusional.
context_findings.quote: If you want to improve society, you should just always act the way you wish people would act. It's like, no? What? What are you talking about? Are you crazy? You know what happens if you always act the way that you wish other people would act? You become fucking Ned Flanders from The Simpsons.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that to succeed as a politics streamer, one must abandon intellectual honesty, as changing one's mind alienates their audience, thus requiring a creator to be either a grifter or unintelligent.
context_findings.quote: To be a successful politics streamer you have to be completely dead set on all your beliefs. Even if it's completely unfounded. So it kind of necessitates that as a politics streamer you're either grifting or stupid.

context_findings.summary: Kaze questions modern economic structures, wondering why massive increases in productivity due to technology haven't resulted in significantly less work for individuals to meet their basic needs.
context_findings.quote: The human race now, with all the automation, is probably literally like a thousand times more productive... So how come we don't have like literally 5 minutes of work a day? Doesn't make sense, right?

context_findings.summary: He discussed potentially getting a sponsor for his F3 event to justify the cost of production, including paying his editor.
When his wife, Zeina, appeared in chat, Kaze jokingly downplayed their codependence.
context_findings.quote: What's your life without keys? Probably basically the same. We don't really need each other that much.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges that focusing solely on produced YouTube videos would be far more lucrative than streaming, but he chooses not to for personal reasons.
context_findings.quote: If I just made YouTube videos, I think I could pretty easily get like... Just from YouTube videos, maybe like 60,000-70,000 a year. Maybe I should do that, man. That's a fuckton of money. But I don't want to.

biobak.summary: Kaze suggested that Biobak should also download the new F64 renderer for Blender, implying Biobak uses the same toolchain and might benefit from the performance improvements.

zeina.summary: Zeina had a brief, lighthearted interaction in chat, prompting a joking response from Kaze about their relationship dynamic.

key_stories.title: The Blender Performance Nightmare
key_stories.summary: Kaze's workflow was halted by severe performance issues in a new Blender update. After resisting, he followed community advice to install a fan-made N64-specific renderer, which solved the problem and allowed him to continue working efficiently.
key_stories.challenge: The latest version of Blender was so slow and resource-heavy that it was becoming impossible for Kaze to do any 3D modeling work.
key_stories.process: Kaze expressed extreme frustration with Blender's performance. Community member Lila persistently recommended he install the F64 renderer. After initial reluctance and jokes, Kaze downloaded and installed the add-on, immediately noticing a significant speed increase.
key_stories.outcome: The F64 renderer dramatically improved performance, allowing work to continue. While it introduced minor visual inaccuracies (like decal emulation), it was a massive net benefit and solved the critical workflow bottleneck.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, it's actually unreasonable to work with this. What the fuck? I might have to go back to an old Blender version just because of this.

key_stories.title: The Case of the Disappearing Hair
key_stories.summary: Kaze debugged a recurring issue where Mario's hair would disappear. He traced the problem to a project setting that was automatically re-enabling itself, highlighting the complex and sometimes obscure nature of working with a custom development toolchain.
key_stories.challenge: An obscure, automatically enabled setting in the project's configuration file was causing bugs, such as Mario's hair disappearing upon export.
key_stories.process: Kaze noticed Mario's hair was missing after an export. He suspected it was related to the 'write all' setting. He investigated the project's JSON configuration file and discovered the setting was re-enabling itself upon loading a file. He then disabled the master setting controlling this behavior.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified that the 'write all' setting was being enabled by the 'auto node repo settings' feature. By turning this feature off, he stopped the unwanted behavior and fixed the bug with Mario's hair.
key_stories.key_quote: The option that breaks if you don't have bleed activated turns itself on whenever you open the... I don't want bleed and write all on over the entire repo because I can't use it without bleed.

key_stories.title: The Luigi Reveal
key_stories.summary: Kaze imported Luigi into the game, revealing him as a new addition. However, he clarified that the character's role is not yet decided, floating ideas like co-op gameplay or a simple unlockable as a throwback to classic Mario 64 rumors.
key_stories.challenge: The team wants to include Luigi in the game, but his exact role and implementation are not yet defined.
key_stories.process: Kaze introduced Luigi as the stream's "special guest" early on. He later imported the model and, upon seeing it in-game during testing, feigned surprise to create a reveal moment. He then openly brainstormed potential uses for the character with the chat.
key_stories.outcome: Luigi's model is now successfully imported into the game. His final role remains an open design question, with possibilities ranging from a full co-op partner to an unlockable character that serves as a nod to old fan theories.
key_stories.key_quote: So Co-op confirmed? Well, I'm not 100% sure exactly how Luigi ties into this yet. Co-op would be the coolest option.

open_questions.context: Kaze has imported a Luigi model and confirmed he will be in the game, but stated, 'I'm not 100% sure exactly how Luigi ties into this yet.' He mentioned co-op as the 'coolest option' but also discussed making him a simple unlockable.
questions: What was the initial motivation for adding Luigi? Was it a long-term plan or a recent idea?
What are the biggest technical and design hurdles to implementing co-op gameplay?
If co-op isn't feasible, what other roles are you considering for Luigi beyond a simple character swap?
How does the team (Biobak, Zeina) feel about the added workload of a second playable character?

open_questions.context: A side level concept was discussed where the player infiltrates an oil tanker to unlock a course named 'Oily Body Bay'. Kaze said the idea of a mission to unlock a side level was 'a crazy idea' that he liked.
questions: How did the concept for the 'Oily Body Bay' side mission originate?
What does the formal design and approval process for a new level idea look like on the team?
Kaze mentioned making side levels in a 'day or two'. Is that realistic, and what does that compressed timeline mean for the art and music contributions from Biobak and Badub?

open_questions.context: When asked about a PAL version of the game, Kaze stated, 'For me Pala right now is in the background. That will have to be an afterthought.'
questions: What are the main technical challenges you anticipate when creating a PAL version?
Is PAL support something the team feels is important for the project's release, or is it more of a 'nice to have' if time permits?
How does targeting NTSC primarily affect design decisions, particularly around game speed and timing?

open_questions.context: Kaze expressed severe frustration with the official Blender software's performance, which was only solved by a community-made tool (F64 Renderer). He also debugged an obscure bug caused by an auto-enabling setting in a config file.
questions: Can you walk me through the custom toolchain you use? What are the biggest benefits and drawbacks of building on top of the decompilation project?
How much time is spent fighting the tools versus actual creative work?
How critical are community tool developers like Lila to the project's progress? How does that collaboration work?
Has the reliance on this specific, sometimes fragile, toolset ever made you consider stopping the project?
